et: Middle English {it}cas{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}casus{/it}, translation of Greek {it}ptōsis{/it}, literally, fall

dt: {bc}an inflectional form of a noun, pronoun, or adjective indicating its grammatical relation to other words
{bc}such a relation whether indicated by inflection or not

{bc}oneself considered as an object of harassment or criticism

pt: {sc}instance{/sc} {sc}case{/sc} {sc}illustration{/sc} {sc}example{/sc} {sc}sample{/sc} {sc}specimen{/sc} mean something that exhibits distinguishing characteristics in its category. {sc}instance{/sc} applies to any individual person, act, or thing that may be offered to illustrate or explain.
{sc}case{/sc} is used to direct attention to a real or assumed occurrence or situation that is to be considered, studied, or dealt with.
{sc}illustration{/sc} applies to an instance offered as a means of clarifying or illuminating a general statement.
{sc}example{/sc} applies to a typical, representative, or illustrative instance or case.
{sc}sample{/sc} implies a part or unit taken at random from a larger whole and so presumed to be typical of its qualities.

pt.t: show us a {it}sample{/it} of your work

pt: {sc}specimen{/sc} applies to any example or sample whether representative or merely existent and available.

pt.t: one of the finest {it}specimens{/it} of the jeweler's art

et: Middle English {it}cas{/it}, from Anglo-French, from Latin {it}casus{/it} fall, chance, from {it}cadere{/it} to fall {ma}{mat|chance|}{/ma}
shortdef: a set of circumstances or conditions
a situation requiring investigation or action (as by the police)
the object of investigation or consideration

dt: {bc}the ratio between deaths and confirmed or reported cases of a specific disease or medical condition within a given time period

dt.t: Among the immunocompetent patients who had invasive pneumococcal infections caused by serotypes represented in the vaccine, the {wi}case fatality rate{/wi} was 33 percent (23 of 70) among those who had been vaccinated and 25 percent (186 of 738) among those who had not.
If untreated, the {wi}case-fatality rate{/wi} of inhaled anthrax exceeds 80%.

shortdef: the ratio between deaths and confirmed or reported cases of a specific disease or medical condition within a given time period —abbreviation CFR
